I was afraid to go out to the street, afraid maybe I wouldn’t make it to the phone, or worse, someone I called would say, “Well, yeah, I didn’t want to say it, but you’re pretty much a piece of shit. He’s right.” The heaves kept coming, bigger and louder waves crashing over me.
Heather:


Tori and I grew up together in three different
countries, in an extremely dysfunctional family. Our parents were never on the
same page, and argued very passively for years. The combination of all this had
us girls rather mixed up, culturally and emotionally. We were all unhappy at
different points in our lives, and experienced rather a lot of trauma while we
were growing up, and even well into our adulthood. Three of us wrote about it
intermittently through the years as a means of expression and release. As a
musician, I also wrote songs for the same reason.  We all found our creative outlets, and unfortunately our not so creative vices, and I wrote about that in song and prose as well. Thank God for my journals...and even the vices I depended on, in moderation, of course. They saved me from slipping through the cracks of my bitterly lonely home life. Let me rewind a bit.The first time our family moved to Japan was in the fifties, after the war and when Dad was working as a diplomat in the American Embassy in downtown Tokyo. He was also chief interpreter of the war crime trials being held in Manila, and was driven to moving up in rank as a marine. For that reason, he was not as present as many dads can be in the dynamic of the family. You could tell he always had more important things on his mind. As his daughters, we thought that no matter what was really going on in his head, that perhaps we had done something wrong, that we were to blame for his aloof, uninterested, and quite often stern approach to interacting with us, or not interacting at all.  Mom had her own way of coping with his lack of interest in her or the family, and got involved with the Christian Science church community in Tokyo, while falling in love with the posh life of living high on the horse in a beautiful, safe city. She was rather a home body and liked her privacy, and in Japan, no one pestered her to come and socialize. She could attend church and maybe an after church event, take the kids to brunch at the Sanno Hotel, the downtown military hotel where we ate and swam at the pool after church, shopped at the PX, and watched matinees. She'd then spend the rest of the week in her quiet home in Azabu, a part of Tokyo that was as lovely as a country neighborhood, right there in the middle of the city. The streets were lined with trees, there were parks with blossoms that brought beautiful bright colors to the neighborhoods in spring and summer. Behind the huge skyscrapers and grand hotels, there were tiny little streets with little stores that had bread and candy, fresh fruits and vegetables, and little markets with friendly merchants who shouted out their welcoming invitations to buy their fresh meat and fish. Vendors  sang of hot sweet potatoes and delicious noodles  while toting their carts around the little streets, bringing sweet and tangy smells to our noses on cold winter days. There were of course, in other parts of the city, huge department stores much like the ones in Chicago that Mom loved as a child. In later years it would become my city, my beloved Tokyo, where there was this feeling of well-being that held me together, as my family life began to fall apart.
                                                                      * * *I ask myself - how could I have let that man have his way with me? Why did he think it was perfectly ok to ask me if he could touch my breast when I was barely thirteen? Why did I not say, no!! You can't!! I can't find the answer. It is so deeply embedded in my troubled soul that I suppose in writing about it, those answers may surface. For now all I can do is tell you about it, dear reader, let the story unfold on its own. Perhaps you will know the answer before I even do.

Tori : Here are some statistics I found that are alarming,
but true, and why we know there are so many who need help :
· 
Every 9 seconds in the US a woman is assaulted or beaten.  –Domestic Violence Statistics
·  . Around
the world, at least one in every three women has been beaten, coerced into sex
or otherwise abused during her lifetime. Most often, the abuser is a member of
her own family. - Domestic Violence Statistics
·  Nearly
one-third of American women (31 percent) report being physically or sexually
abused by a husband or boyfriend at some point in their lives. Source:
Commonwealth Fund survey, 1998
·  Nearly
2 in 3 female victims of violence were related to or knew their attacker.
Source: Commonwealth Fund survey, 1998
· 
Based on the reports we have, it's
conservatively believed that in today's society 1 in 4 girls and 1 in 6 boys
WILL BE sexually molested before they are 18 years old -- which means 1 in 5 of
America's youth, or fully 20% to 25% of the population !!  -National Association of Adult Survivors of Child Abuse 
Heather : Which leads me to talk about something
else that is really, really important. There are things that happened to me and
things I did to myself, things I hadn’t really connected with having been
abused. They are very difficult to talk or write about, but are crucial in getting
through the healing process, and I want to tell you a bit about that now. Not
long ago, I happened to come across a list of symptoms of sexual abuse. It was
shocking to realize that these symptoms had or have been haunting me for
decades. These are the kinds of things we don’t talk about at parties, things
we don’t even want to admit to ourselves. Here is that list with a short
introduction, which struck me like thunder.
Child sexual abuse (CSA)
has lifelong effects.  Adults who are survivors of CSA often report a
feeling of being “stuck”.  Their efforts to build and manage their lives
often seem fruitless, hollow, or even hopeless.  There can be a persistent
perception that they are somehow different from others. They commonly
report feeling that they are on the outside looking in or believe that they
just don’t belong. The
adult symptoms of childhood abuse can take many forms.  Many adult
survivors may:

Find
     it difficult to develop or maintain close personal relationships.
Have
     a strong desire to live in isolation or to “hide out” from life.
Endure
     physical ailments like neck, back, stomach and gynecological problems that
     persist despite efforts at good self-care.
Experience
     feelings of sadness, fear and anger that often seem unmanageable or
     overwhelming.
Undergo
     panics, rages, depressions, sleep disorders, or self-mutilation or have
     suicidal thoughts.
Find
     themselves depending on alcohol, other drugs, or may develop eating
     disorders to cover feelings of humiliation, shame and low self-esteem.
Experience
     problems like low self-esteem, avoidance of sex, promiscuity, or inability
     to experience sexual pleasure.
Exhibit
     signs of trauma like panic attacks, numbing of body areas, and feeling of
     being disconnected from their bodies.

Now, a person can read these symptoms and get some
kind of statistical knowledge of what this is about, and even identify with it
to a point. But until you get into how these things come about, how they are
interwoven into our daily lives over the years, it really doesn’t compute. Not
in any way that is clear. What I feel, and what I read here in these
statistics, are indeed connected, but the only way I can communicate it to you
in a way that brings clarity to myself and my readers (hopefully!) is to relate
it to you in a creatively flowing way, in my story. Because this
is something so deep within our souls that it rarely sees the light of day. But
boy, does it ever need to be cleared from the cobwebs, and brought back into the light. This is my, and Tori's wish for this book.

story:
"Why couldn’t things go back to the way they used to be? When she was in school, didn’t have two hot guys to choose between, was clueless about the
supernatural world and wasn’t the devil’s daughter, but just Angelica."

At first glance Angelica is gorgeous, lives in a mansion with her two aunts, goes to a prestigious private school and has everything a teenager could want. That is until a few days before her 16th birthday she begins to have weird dreams,hallucinations, and paranoia of being watched. 

Suddenly one of her aunts is attacked.  Angelica is surprised when she learns  the attack occurred because her aunt was protecting Angelica from her father, Lucifer.  He has plans for Angelica whether she likes them or not.

Angelica is suddenly thrust into a dangerous, magical world. She finds out that no one is as they seem, magic is real and evil is lurking around every corner. She has to make a decision to run, fight or wait for the darkness to consume her.


Who Are You

My name is Tamekia Hayden and I am a single mother of four kids as well as an aspiring author. Somehow between working a full time job, attending school full time and tending to four kids between the ages of 7-15, I have managed to write a  young adult fantasy book called Waiting For The Beast. I have written a number of short stories in the past, but have never had the guts to publish or submit any of them until now.

What Are You Doing With My Contribution


I want to publish a beautiful book inside and out. I read somewhere "If you invest nothing in your book, don’t expect readers to be very impressed, or compelled to buy it" and "even if you create a beautiful product, wonderfully written with professional presentation, if no one hears about it, your book will sit untouched online, gathering virtual dust." With that being said here is what I need:
  • Editing $900
  • Cover Design $200
  • Book Formatting & Layout $250
  • Ebook Conversion $150

Every contribution touches my soul because that means you believe in my dream. I know words aren't enough to express my gratitude for your contribution so I definitely have some perks for you. The more you contribute, the bigger the perk. If you decide that you don't want a perk and you contribute a different amount that's fine, but you still will receive a thank you from me either by email or a shout out on my Facebook page. There is no getting away from my gratitude!

If I don't reach my goal I will take what I have and put it towards the publishing of my book. Either way I will keep you updated every step of the way and on every aspect of what I am doing with your contributions. And I will make sure that you still get whatever perk was promised  to you.

How Will My Contribution Make A Difference

There are so many women who are talented, but because they have other things going on in their life such as  being a single parent, struggling financially, consumed with work, or a stay at home mom they forget about what makes them happy. They let their talents go to waste. If I can publish my book  this will inspire my daughters, my sisters, my girlfriends, and other women all over the world that no matter what is going on in your life,never lose sight of your dreams. Go after them! I can't promise you that you will like my book. You might even hate it lol. What I can promise you is that if you contribute I will see this through to the end and get it published. Failing is not an option and it definitely won't be one with your help.

But I Can't Contribute
That's okay! There are plenty of other ways you can help me.

  • Spread the word about my campaign
  • Use the campaign share buttons to share on social media 
  • Follow me on Twitter or like my Facebook page
  • Blog about Waiting For The Beast and my campaign
  • If you are an editor, web designer, agent, publisher, marketing agency and you want to volunteer to help me, please do!

story:
Why would you want to go NowHere?

Because it is the opposite of nowhere. NowHere is a state of consciousness that we are all familiar with. It is where we came from and where we will return to. It is always here now, and when you learn to enter it mindfully, you will see the consequences of the choices made every moment by the conscious beings that we share this reality with.

To learn more, you will have to read NowHere. But first, you have to help create it. 

What is this picture?

The cover of the novel NowHere is a photo of the hand-embroidered image I created of the Earth from NASA's website, with hurricanes and cyclones arranged to create the Yin Yang symbol of balance. The lines orbiting the planet are electroluminous wire, which is powered by a battery pack to flash in unison. They represent the energy fields that exist in the universe, and the paths of time that the characters in the book can manipulate in their effort to recreate their reality.

About me:

My name is Mardeen Smyth Gordon, I am 52 years old and I live in Ben Lomond, CA, in the redwood forest near Santa Cruz. I am an artist, writer, percussionist and creator of things that make you go "Wow!"

Many years ago, a story began to take shape in my mind, and it evolved and grew with my life experience, incorporating all that I have learned about the nature of reality, cosmology, physics and meta-physics into the story of NowHere.

About the book:

NowHere is neither a time nor a place, but an intersection of layers of reality, where humans are able to interact with the universal forces to influence the future of existence. Threads of possible futures pass through NowHere like ripples in the fabric of space and time, and it is up to Merridy and the other Websters to choose the path that will bring the Earth back from the devastation of nuclear war.

About the campaign:

NowHere is ready to share with the world, and the best way to do it is by self-publishing. But this costs money, so I am asking for your support.

If the campaign raises the full goal amount, I will be able to utilize all of the editing, publishing, and promotional services offered by Lulu.com to sell the book in stores and online in both printed and electronic formats worldwide.

If the campaign falls short of the goal, I will have to limit the scope of the publishing and promotion, but I will still get my book into print, and all of the perks will be delivered to those who contribute.

Where the money goes:

Depending on the amount raised, 7%-12% goes into the fees for hosting and collecting the funds.

Between $5,000.00 and $8,000.00 will be spent for editing, publishing, and promotion

Approximately 38% of the funds raised will be used to pay for the production and delivery of the perks to contributors.

Whatever is left over will allow me to focus on editing, publishing and spreading the word about NowHere.

Why it matters:

At the core of the story is a revelation about the nature of reality and our ability to create the future that will seize your imagination.  If it inspires readers to believe in their dreams, I will know that it was worth writing.

What if you can't contribute? Or even if you can:

If want to help, share this on your Facebook page, by email or Twitter, or try using the Indiegogo share tools.

This is the first chapter:

“Merridy, will you see me in my office after lunch?”

Mr. Diehl doesn’t even look at her as his pudgy fingers tap her desk on his way past. His voice is gruff and monotonous as usual, giving no clue as to what he wants to discuss with her.

She sits with a mouthful of tuna salad sandwich, staring at the broad expanse of his blue dress shirt as he waddles through the door of his corner office, closing it behind him.

'Why do I eat my lunch at my desk? I could be sitting out in the park feeding the birds, instead of letting him ruin my appetite. I’ll bet this is about the Main Street account. He probably wants to know why they cancelled half of the brochures. Or maybe he just wants to rag on me for being late again.'

She pulls out the Main Street files as she crams the last few bites of sandwich into her mouth, drops the Vitamin Water, chips and brownie back into the paper bag and deposits it under her desk for later. 

Scanning the headlines scrolling across the bottom of her computer screen, it seems every other one is something about Pakistan. Nothing new, there. A calendar alert pops up reminding her about the “End of the World Party” on 12-21. Tomorrow is her one night off from Denny's, and she smiles, picturing herself lounging between Jack's legs, passing a joint around and celebrating MisJudgement Day with her friends.

A click on her home e-mail account shows a message from Indymac regarding her mortgage. Probably just a reminder that she must pay by the 30th to avoid another $100.00 late fee. 

'Fat chance. My house is worth half what it was a year ago, but my mortgage payment just doubled. How do you explain that? They don’t pay me enough here to keep up with the rising interest rates. Good luck finding another job, though.'

Her lips twist in a sarcastic sneer. 

'I better go start kissing Mr. Diehl’s fat ass.' 

Swallowing the last of the sandwich, she stands and heads for his office, files tucked under her arm.

She knocks lightly on Mr. Diehl’s door, just underneath the engraved sign reading WARREN DIEHL, PRESIDENT.

“Come in.” 

She sucks in a breath as she opens the door, filling her lungs with one last breath of clean air before immersing herself in the swirl of stale cigar smoke that is Mr. Diehl’s lair.

He is leaning back in his overloaded executive chair, the armrests almost obscured by the spread of his belly hanging over them. He gestures for her to take a seat in the threadbare wooden frame chair in front of his desk, and she tries not to let the disgust show on her face as he gurgles loudly and spits into a yellowed handkerchief, clearing his throat for the thousandth time today.

“Merridy, you have been with Such a Diehl Printing for eight years now, and you have proven yourself to be an effective manager; your projects are usually completed on time, and the other employees seem to like you.” He tilts his head down to peer over the bifocals perched on the fleshy hills of his cheeks. “Perhaps a bit too much.”

Does he know about Jack and me? I knew I shouldn’t have let him walk me to my car last week.

When she doesn’t respond to his goading, he continues. “Your sales record, however, leaves much to be desired. Once you get a hold of an account, it seems the volume starts to head downhill. Even regular customers, like Main Street, have been reducing their orders in the past six months. We’re supposed to up sell, not downsize.” Each sentence is punctuated by a slurping intake of air, making him sound like he is drowning in his own phlegm. 

She opens the file and lets out the reserved breath, suppressing a cough and preparing to explain when Mr. Diehl raises his hand, like five plump sausages attached to a pork chop, to cut her off.

“Now, I understand that times are hard for everyone right now, and I wouldn’t want to send you packing without giving you a chance to redeem yourself. You take those sales leads I gave you last week and make some calls, and I’m sure you will be able to turn this thing around. You can wear that headset we got you so you don’t get a cramp in your neck. And it wouldn’t hurt to get an earlier start every day.” 

The hand plops back down on the desk, and Merridy understands that she has been dismissed. She rises, tucks the file back under her arm, and exits the office without a backward glance. Phoebe peers through her bangs with a pitying gaze, but quickly looks down and starts shuffling papers upon catching the laser beams from Merridy’s eyes.

The rest of the day is spent in strained silence, except for her furious typing of e-mails and printing of contact lists. Nothing can make her wear that headset, or anything else that wraps around her head, reminding her of duct tape and cigarettes…But she will call every single one of those customers tomorrow, and damned if that pompous old snotbag is going to blame the collapse of the economy on her. 

Sure, her sales accounts have been slipping; all of their regular customers have cut back on their advertising budgets, and some have even gone out of business. Nobody else spends any time dealing with customers’ accounts, and the old man hasn’t even answered the phone himself since Phoebe came along three years ago. If anyone deserves to be “sent packing”, it’s her, with her squeaky voice and her perky little “Howdy, Phoebe here!” What does she think this is, Cowboy Printing?

He does have a point about being on time, though. She sees the smirks on the crew’s faces, and it makes it hard to get a good start every day, even if she is only ten minutes late. It’s just so hard to get up in the morning when you’ve been waiting tables at Denny’s until 2:00 AM.

As soon as the clock flips to 5:00, she closes the work files and starts to shut down the computer. The last window open behind everything else is her Facebook page, with a new message from her mother on her wall.

Merridy’s Mom - Will you go with me tomorrow to see Dr. Bleier? I’m sure he can squeeze you in to get that mammogram you’ve been putting off…get it, SQUEEZE you in? LOL ;)

She rolls her eyes and blows her bangs up off her forehead. “Oh, mom. Just because you put a funny little note on my wall doesn’t mean it’s not still nagging. And don’t you think you’re a bit old for the text tags and emoticons? Besides, I can’t drive you to the city tomorrow, I’ve got a big day of groveling and begging ahead of me.”

Her fingers slip under the sleeve of her Such A Diehl T-shirt to slide gently over the smooth, raised circles of scars clustered there.

“She’s just trying to help, you know.”

Phoebe jumps back as Merridy sends her chair rolling off the carpet mat and spins around, ready to tell her off for reading over her shoulder, for butting in, for being so damn cute all the time. But the look on her face stops Merridy cold. She is biting her lip, clutching her hands to her chest, and her big, blue eyes look genuinely terrified. She looks like she is actually about to cry.

“I’m sorry, Phoebe. Did my chair roll over your toe? It’s just been a really rough day, and I’ve got to change and get to Denny’s by 6:00 if I want to get any dinner. Are you OK?”

Phoebe takes a quick breath and wipes her eyes, then runs both hands back through her blonde curls. It must be hard to be taken seriously when you look like a miniature version of Marilyn Monroe. She can’t be more than five feet tall, even with the spiked heels. The low-cut blouses and perfect makeup usually complete the picture of the self-assured Southern Belle, but right now she looks more like a china doll that is about to shatter into a million pieces.

“Have y’all been payin' attention to the news today? I’m really scared. Somethin’ is goin’ on ovah in Pakistan, and I don’t think it’s just goin' to blow ovah this time. They’re mobilizin' the troops in Afghanistan and massin' along the bordah, and you know my Bo is ovah theyah. I just don’t know what I would do if somethin’ happened to him. I wish his tour hadn’t been extended again…”

It takes at least fifteen minutes to listen sympathetically to Phoebe’s worries, calm her down and reassure her that the world is not about to end, finish shutting down her computer and dash into the bathroom to change into her waitress uniform. She is trotting across the street, digging the keys out of her purse to push the unlock button when she realizes she left her uneaten lunch under the desk. 'Shit.' Well, hopefully the rats won’t find it before tomorrow. 'What the hell is that?'

The paper tucked under her windshield wiper is a plain white, number 10 business sized envelope, and as she pulls it out she sees the Such A Diehl return address printed in the corner. She opens the door and plops into the driver’s seat, slipping her fingers under the unsealed flap with a worried look on her face. The note inside is handwritten on yellow lined tablet paper, folded rather unevenly.

Merridy,

I’m sorry to have to tell you this way, but I think we have to stop seeing each other (except at work, of course.) I know the Big Diehl doesn’t like employees “fraternizing”, but it’s more than that. You’re older than I am, you have your own house and everything, and I just don’t think I’m really what you’re looking for. You need a man who can be a husband and start a family, and I’m not even ready for that.

I hope you can understand. If you want to talk about it, I’ll be around this weekend. 

Jack

Merridy lets the papers fall, crosses her arms on the steering wheel and bangs her forehead into them several times, punctuating each blow with a “Shit! Shit! Shit! Shit! Shit!” 

It’s been a long time since she really let loose with a good cry, and this seems as good a time as any. Everything is falling apart, and she can’t do anything to stop it. The moan rises from deep in her chest, pouring out along with the tears, filling the car with her sobs of frustration. It feels good to let it all out, instead of listening to that sarcastic voice in her head and trying to deny how crappy it all makes her feel. 

She listens to herself bawling like a ten-year-old, and thinks maybe she should take the day off tomorrow and go to the city with her mom. After all, the world is going to end, so what does she have to lose? She snatches a Kleenex from the box on the floor, wipes her eyes and blows her nose, but she’s not quite done yet. Listening to herself taking one more shuddering breath, sitting there in a Denny’s uniform, the ridiculousness of her situation hits her, and she looks around to make sure nobody is walking anywhere nearby.

Twisting to look back over her right shoulder, she is embarrassed to see that her despair did indeed have an audience. Sitting on the tiny porch of a duplex apartment is an old woman wearing a bathrobe, fuzzy slippers, and a knitted ski cap with four points tipped with tassels.

Her face is so wrinkled that it looks like crumpled parchment, bunched up around a gap-toothed grin. She is nodding and raising one claw-like hand toward Merridy, gesturing to come closer. Though she appears to be nearly one hundred years old and probably suffering from dementia, her eyes are clear and bright, a gleaming sapphire blue that communicate an unmistakable intelligence. 

Staring into those eyes, Merridy realizes that everything she is wearing is blue, though in wildly mismatched shades. She is certainly interested in Merridy, leaning forward to grab her walker and struggling to rise from the blue plastic chair crammed into a corner of the porch.

Merridy is frozen in fascination, watching the old woman over her shoulder as she pulls herself upright and shuffles toward the porch steps, never breaking eye contact. It is only when the front of the walker scoots off the edge of the porch that Merridy spins around, throws open her door and bolts around the back of her car to keep the old woman from tumbling down the stairs.

She hesitates by the bumper, one foot on the curb, when the old woman chuckles knowingly and points one gnarled finger at Merridy, as she stands poised precariously with one hand on her walker, still teetering with one leg hovering in the air.

Now the wizened face loses all traces of merriment, the wrinkles rearrange themselves into a serious combination of furrowed brows and pursed lips, and the hand raises up to point over Merridy’s head to the ridge of mountains behind her, in the direction of her home.

Still holding her gaze with those crystal blue eyes, the old woman croaks one word in a voice as dry and ancient as a mummy.

“Go!”

The spell is finally broken when the hand drops back down to maneuver the walker back around onto the porch and the old woman shuffles off through the door of her duplex, slamming it behind her.

Merridy shakes her head and stares down into the gutter, wondering what the hell that was all about.

“I do have to go, but I won’t be heading home for quite a while, yet. In fact, if I don’t get a move on, I’m gonna be late for the second time today.”

She plops into the driver’s seat, searching for her keys on the cushion beside her. She finds them under Jack’s note, and snatches it up in her left hand as she jams the keys into the ignition and starts the car with a satisfying roar.

A harsh laugh escapes her now, and she rips the note into several pieces and shoves it into the trash bag hanging off of the gearshift. 

“You’re right, you are too young for me, Jack. I should have been the one to cut you loose.” She pulls down the sun visor and checks out her face in the mirror. At least her eyes aren’t too red. Not that it matters. Nobody at Denny’s cares what’s going on with her, anyway.
story_txt: Why would you want to go NowHere?Because it is the opposite of nowhere. NowHere is a state of consciousness that we are all familiar with. It is where we came from and where we will return to. It is always here now, and when you learn to enter it mindfully, you will see the consequences of the choices made every moment by the conscious beings that we share this reality with.To learn more, you will have to read NowHere. But first, you have to help create it. What is this picture?The cover of the novel NowHere is a photo of the hand-embroidered image I created of the Earth from NASA's website, with hurricanes and cyclones arranged to create the Yin Yang symbol of balance. The lines orbiting the planet are electroluminous wire, which is powered by a battery pack to flash in unison. They represent the energy fields that exist in the universe, and the paths of time that the characters in the book can manipulate in their effort to recreate their reality.About me:My name is Mardeen Smyth Gordon, I am 52 years old and I live in Ben Lomond, CA, in the redwood forest near Santa Cruz. I am an artist, writer, percussionist and creator of things that make you go "Wow!"Many years ago, a story began to take shape in my mind, and it evolved and grew with my life experience, incorporating all that I have learned about the nature of reality, cosmology, physics and meta-physics into the story of NowHere.About the book:NowHere is neither a time nor a place, but an intersection of layers of reality, where humans are able to interact with the universal forces to influence the future of existence. Threads of possible futures pass through NowHere like ripples in the fabric of space and time, and it is up to Merridy and the other Websters to choose the path that will bring the Earth back from the devastation of nuclear war.About the campaign:NowHere is ready to share with the world, and the best way to do it is by self-publishing. But this costs money, so I am asking for your support.If the campaign raises the full goal amount, I will be able to utilize all of the editing, publishing, and promotional services offered by Lulu.com to sell the book in stores and online in both printed and electronic formats worldwide.If the campaign falls short of the goal, I will have to limit the scope of the publishing and promotion, but I will still get my book into print, and all of the perks will be delivered to those who contribute.Where the money goes:Depending on the amount raised, 7%-12% goes into the fees for hosting and collecting the funds.Between $5,000.00 and $8,000.00 will be spent for editing, publishing, and promotionApproximately 38% of the funds raised will be used to pay for the production and delivery of the perks to contributors.Whatever is left over will allow me to focus on editing, publishing and spreading the word about NowHere.Why it matters:At the core of the story is a revelation about the nature of reality and our ability to create the future that will seize your imagination.  If it inspires readers to believe in their dreams, I will know that it was worth writing.What if you can't contribute? Or even if you can:If want to help, share this on your Facebook page, by email or Twitter, or try using the Indiegogo share tools.This is the first chapter:“Merridy, will you see me in my office after lunch?”Mr. Diehl doesn’t even look at her as his pudgy fingers tap her desk on his way past. His voice is gruff and monotonous as usual, giving no clue as to what he wants to discuss with her.She sits with a mouthful of tuna salad sandwich, staring at the broad expanse of his blue dress shirt as he waddles through the door of his corner office, closing it behind him.'Why do I eat my lunch at my desk? I could be sitting out in the park feeding the birds, instead of letting him ruin my appetite. I’ll bet this is about the Main Street account. He probably wants to know why they cancelled half of the brochures. Or maybe he just wants to rag on me for being late again.'She pulls out the Main Street files as she crams the last few bites of sandwich into her mouth, drops the Vitamin Water, chips and brownie back into the paper bag and deposits it under her desk for later. Scanning the headlines scrolling across the bottom of her computer screen, it seems every other one is something about Pakistan. Nothing new, there. A calendar alert pops up reminding her about the “End of the World Party” on 12-21. Tomorrow is her one night off from Denny's, and she smiles, picturing herself lounging between Jack's legs, passing a joint around and celebrating MisJudgement Day with her friends.A click on her home e-mail account shows a message from Indymac regarding her mortgage. Probably just a reminder that she must pay by the 30th to avoid another $100.00 late fee. 'Fat chance. My house is worth half what it was a year ago, but my mortgage payment just doubled. How do you explain that? They don’t pay me enough here to keep up with the rising interest rates. Good luck finding another job, though.'Her lips twist in a sarcastic sneer. 'I better go start kissing Mr. Diehl’s fat ass.' Swallowing the last of the sandwich, she stands and heads for his office, files tucked under her arm.She knocks lightly on Mr. Diehl’s door, just underneath the engraved sign reading WARREN DIEHL, PRESIDENT.“Come in.” She sucks in a breath as she opens the door, filling her lungs with one last breath of clean air before immersing herself in the swirl of stale cigar smoke that is Mr. Diehl’s lair.He is leaning back in his overloaded executive chair, the armrests almost obscured by the spread of his belly hanging over them. He gestures for her to take a seat in the threadbare wooden frame chair in front of his desk, and she tries not to let the disgust show on her face as he gurgles loudly and spits into a yellowed handkerchief, clearing his throat for the thousandth time today.“Merridy, you have been with Such a Diehl Printing for eight years now, and you have proven yourself to be an effective manager; your projects are usually completed on time, and the other employees seem to like you.” He tilts his head down to peer over the bifocals perched on the fleshy hills of his cheeks. “Perhaps a bit too much.”Does he know about Jack and me? I knew I shouldn’t have let him walk me to my car last week.When she doesn’t respond to his goading, he continues. “Your sales record, however, leaves much to be desired. Once you get a hold of an account, it seems the volume starts to head downhill. Even regular customers, like Main Street, have been reducing their orders in the past six months. We’re supposed to up sell, not downsize.” Each sentence is punctuated by a slurping intake of air, making him sound like he is drowning in his own phlegm. She opens the file and lets out the reserved breath, suppressing a cough and preparing to explain when Mr. Diehl raises his hand, like five plump sausages attached to a pork chop, to cut her off.“Now, I understand that times are hard for everyone right now, and I wouldn’t want to send you packing without giving you a chance to redeem yourself. You take those sales leads I gave you last week and make some calls, and I’m sure you will be able to turn this thing around. You can wear that headset we got you so you don’t get a cramp in your neck. And it wouldn’t hurt to get an earlier start every day.” The hand plops back down on the desk, and Merridy understands that she has been dismissed. She rises, tucks the file back under her arm, and exits the office without a backward glance. Phoebe peers through her bangs with a pitying gaze, but quickly looks down and starts shuffling papers upon catching the laser beams from Merridy’s eyes.The rest of the day is spent in strained silence, except for her furious typing of e-mails and printing of contact lists. Nothing can make her wear that headset, or anything else that wraps around her head, reminding her of duct tape and cigarettes…But she will call every single one of those customers tomorrow, and damned if that pompous old snotbag is going to blame the collapse of the economy on her. Sure, her sales accounts have been slipping; all of their regular customers have cut back on their advertising budgets, and some have even gone out of business. Nobody else spends any time dealing with customers’ accounts, and the old man hasn’t even answered the phone himself since Phoebe came along three years ago. If anyone deserves to be “sent packing”, it’s her, with her squeaky voice and her perky little “Howdy, Phoebe here!” What does she think this is, Cowboy Printing?He does have a point about being on time, though. She sees the smirks on the crew’s faces, and it makes it hard to get a good start every day, even if she is only ten minutes late. It’s just so hard to get up in the morning when you’ve been waiting tables at Denny’s until 2:00 AM.As soon as the clock flips to 5:00, she closes the work files and starts to shut down the computer. The last window open behind everything else is her Facebook page, with a new message from her mother on her wall.Merridy’s Mom - Will you go with me tomorrow to see Dr. Bleier? I’m sure he can squeeze you in to get that mammogram you’ve been putting off…get it, SQUEEZE you in? LOL ;)She rolls her eyes and blows her bangs up off her forehead. “Oh, mom. Just because you put a funny little note on my wall doesn’t mean it’s not still nagging. And don’t you think you’re a bit old for the text tags and emoticons? Besides, I can’t drive you to the city tomorrow, I’ve got a big day of groveling and begging ahead of me.”Her fingers slip under the sleeve of her Such A Diehl T-shirt to slide gently over the smooth, raised circles of scars clustered there.“She’s just trying to help, you know.”Phoebe jumps back as Merridy sends her chair rolling off the carpet mat and spins around, ready to tell her off for reading over her shoulder, for butting in, for being so damn cute all the time. But the look on her face stops Merridy cold. She is biting her lip, clutching her hands to her chest, and her big, blue eyes look genuinely terrified. She looks like she is actually about to cry.“I’m sorry, Phoebe. Did my chair roll over your toe? It’s just been a really rough day, and I’ve got to change and get to Denny’s by 6:00 if I want to get any dinner. Are you OK?”Phoebe takes a quick breath and wipes her eyes, then runs both hands back through her blonde curls. It must be hard to be taken seriously when you look like a miniature version of Marilyn Monroe. She can’t be more than five feet tall, even with the spiked heels. The low-cut blouses and perfect makeup usually complete the picture of the self-assured Southern Belle, but right now she looks more like a china doll that is about to shatter into a million pieces.“Have y’all been payin' attention to the news today? I’m really scared. Somethin’ is goin’ on ovah in Pakistan, and I don’t think it’s just goin' to blow ovah this time. They’re mobilizin' the troops in Afghanistan and massin' along the bordah, and you know my Bo is ovah theyah. I just don’t know what I would do if somethin’ happened to him. I wish his tour hadn’t been extended again…”It takes at least fifteen minutes to listen sympathetically to Phoebe’s worries, calm her down and reassure her that the world is not about to end, finish shutting down her computer and dash into the bathroom to change into her waitress uniform. She is trotting across the street, digging the keys out of her purse to push the unlock button when she realizes she left her uneaten lunch under the desk. 'Shit.' Well, hopefully the rats won’t find it before tomorrow. 'What the hell is that?'The paper tucked under her windshield wiper is a plain white, number 10 business sized envelope, and as she pulls it out she sees the Such A Diehl return address printed in the corner. She opens the door and plops into the driver’s seat, slipping her fingers under the unsealed flap with a worried look on her face. The note inside is handwritten on yellow lined tablet paper, folded rather unevenly.Merridy,I’m sorry to have to tell you this way, but I think we have to stop seeing each other (except at work, of course.) I know the Big Diehl doesn’t like employees “fraternizing”, but it’s more than that. You’re older than I am, you have your own house and everything, and I just don’t think I’m really what you’re looking for. You need a man who can be a husband and start a family, and I’m not even ready for that.I hope you can understand. If you want to talk about it, I’ll be around this weekend. JackMerridy lets the papers fall, crosses her arms on the steering wheel and bangs her forehead into them several times, punctuating each blow with a “Shit! Shit! Shit! Shit! Shit!” It’s been a long time since she really let loose with a good cry, and this seems as good a time as any. Everything is falling apart, and she can’t do anything to stop it. The moan rises from deep in her chest, pouring out along with the tears, filling the car with her sobs of frustration. It feels good to let it all out, instead of listening to that sarcastic voice in her head and trying to deny how crappy it all makes her feel. She listens to herself bawling like a ten-year-old, and thinks maybe she should take the day off tomorrow and go to the city with her mom. After all, the world is going to end, so what does she have to lose? She snatches a Kleenex from the box on the floor, wipes her eyes and blows her nose, but she’s not quite done yet. Listening to herself taking one more shuddering breath, sitting there in a Denny’s uniform, the ridiculousness of her situation hits her, and she looks around to make sure nobody is walking anywhere nearby.Twisting to look back over her right shoulder, she is embarrassed to see that her despair did indeed have an audience. Sitting on the tiny porch of a duplex apartment is an old woman wearing a bathrobe, fuzzy slippers, and a knitted ski cap with four points tipped with tassels.Her face is so wrinkled that it looks like crumpled parchment, bunched up around a gap-toothed grin. She is nodding and raising one claw-like hand toward Merridy, gesturing to come closer. Though she appears to be nearly one hundred years old and probably suffering from dementia, her eyes are clear and bright, a gleaming sapphire blue that communicate an unmistakable intelligence. Staring into those eyes, Merridy realizes that everything she is wearing is blue, though in wildly mismatched shades. She is certainly interested in Merridy, leaning forward to grab her walker and struggling to rise from the blue plastic chair crammed into a corner of the porch.Merridy is frozen in fascination, watching the old woman over her shoulder as she pulls herself upright and shuffles toward the porch steps, never breaking eye contact. It is only when the front of the walker scoots off the edge of the porch that Merridy spins around, throws open her door and bolts around the back of her car to keep the old woman from tumbling down the stairs.She hesitates by the bumper, one foot on the curb, when the old woman chuckles knowingly and points one gnarled finger at Merridy, as she stands poised precariously with one hand on her walker, still teetering with one leg hovering in the air.Now the wizened face loses all traces of merriment, the wrinkles rearrange themselves into a serious combination of furrowed brows and pursed lips, and the hand raises up to point over Merridy’s head to the ridge of mountains behind her, in the direction of her home.Still holding her gaze with those crystal blue eyes, the old woman croaks one word in a voice as dry and ancient as a mummy.“Go!”The spell is finally broken when the hand drops back down to maneuver the walker back around onto the porch and the old woman shuffles off through the door of her duplex, slamming it behind her.Merridy shakes her head and stares down into the gutter, wondering what the hell that was all about.“I do have to go, but I won’t be heading home for quite a while, yet. In fact, if I don’t get a move on, I’m gonna be late for the second time today.”She plops into the driver’s seat, searching for her keys on the cushion beside her. She finds them under Jack’s note, and snatches it up in her left hand as she jams the keys into the ignition and starts the car with a satisfying roar.A harsh laugh escapes her now, and she rips the note into several pieces and shoves it into the trash bag hanging off of the gearshift. “You’re right, you are too young for me, Jack. I should have been the one to cut you loose.” She pulls down the sun visor and checks out her face in the mirror. At least her eyes aren’t too red. Not that it matters. Nobody at Denny’s cares what’s going on with her, anyway.

story:
Our Mission

Our mission for this project, “Timmy”, is to uncover the permanent and dynamic consequences which are bestowed upon those who know and love the brave soldiers who fall to their death to keep our Country free. Not only do these fallen heroes leave behind widows and grieving children they leave behind mothers, fathers, sisters, brothers, grandparents, friends, communities, and an entire nation to ponder a very simple, yet infinitely complex question.

 Why?


What We Need & What You Get

To get this project started, we need as many resources as possible to write the most accurate and impactful content possible. The published author is in Texas, and many current and former soldiers with valuable input and information are residing all over the country, and even overseas. 

Our goal is to cover the costs of travel funds to allow these courageous soldiers to meet with us in person in California, where the family of Timmy Smith is currently residing. The interview process is going to be one of the most critical in determining the quality and accuracy of this book. 

Our team believes that because everyone expresses themselves differently through writing, phone calls, and other means, we cannot obtain accurate statements which will include emotion, if we do not meet with these individuals in person.

At the bare minimum, the average travel costs for one person plus one family member to fly out to California, as well as lodging, food expenses, and car rental covered for one weekend, will be $1,100 per person. We need Timmy's father, Michael Smith, to come to California all the way from Florida. We can't write this book without him.

We are hoping to have at least four of Timmy’s friends come out to meet with us at the end of July 2014. We also need quality equipment to document our experiences, which we hope to include with the book as a DVD, once it is published. After research, the least-expensive and best quality camera that we can use is the Nikon D5200 which is $799.00.

As of current, our rough estimate of the expenses that it will cost to make this project one which will have a never-ending impact on our future generations and the way that love and war are processed, and essentially tied in to each other, is roughly $14,962. This amount is likely to change, but it is a good estimate of what we need to get started.

  • Every person who contributes to this incredible project of at least $20 will receive the final paperback copy as soon as it is available.
  • Every person who contributes $50 or more will receive a signed paperback copy as soon as it is available.
  • Every person contributing to $100 or more receives the above paperback, as well as a dedication in your name, and a signed documentary DVD.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
• Gagá pa’l pueblo es un ejercicio permanente de construcción comunitaria que  ha impactado a más de 10,000 personas, en sus cuatro años de trabajo constantemente. Ahora para en el cierre de la temporada del 2014 necesitamos tu ayuda para cerrar en grande este año y sobre todo dar las  gracias a la comunidad que nos ha creado y visto crecer. Ayúdanos a devolverles con gratitud.

  • Durante cada verano una gran divercidad de músicos, cantantes, bailadores, fotógrafos, pintores, y personas de la comunidad han hecho posible este esfuerzo colectivo. Es ahora el tiempo de mostrarles nuestra gratitud por su participación constante y cálidad .

  • Con tu contribución económica haremos vibrante a esta comunidad de mujeres y hombres comprometidos con la cultura para seguir forjando lo que será un legado a quienes vendrán después de nosotros.

  •  Ydanis Rodríguez concejal del ditricto 10 de la ciudad de Nueva York haciendo entrega de una proclama a Gagá pa’l pueblo por su labor cultural durante la apertura de la exhibición fotográfica Photographic Songs.

  • Ricardo Ureña impartiendo una clase del baile de los palos.


Para el cierre oficial de Gagá pa’l pueblo del 2014 estamos necesitando $8,000 dólares. Estos fondos irán directamente a los costos de la actividad del 21 de septiembre. Con ellos pagáremos: el sonido, la transportación, el permiso del parque, el permiso de sonido, la comida, la documentación  en fotografía y video, el costo del altar, refrigerios y las placas de reconocimiento. Además de dar algún incentivo a las agrupaciones musicales que se estarán presentando

Detalles del altar del  cierre oficial de Gagá pa’l pueblo 2013


Ayúdanos a alcanzar nuestra meta. Tu contribución es valiosa. 

Ningún aporte es pequeño. Solo importa lo que tú  puedas donar. Hazlo ahora y  sé parte de este esfuerzo colectivo. ¡Haz tu donación ahora! 

No obstante te informamos que, tenemos cuatro categorías de donantes especiales los cuales recibirán un regalo de reconocimiento por  su apoyo a este evento. Las categorías son: Lame, Reyna, Mayor, Mambosa

Lame: los que hagan una contribución de $25 a $50. (10 en total)

Estos recibirán como agradecimiento una camiseta de 

Gagá pa’l pueblo.

Reyna: los que hagan una contribución de $75 a $150. (15 en total)

Estos recibirán como agradecimiento un DVD del cierre oficial de

Gagá pa’l pueblo 2014.

Mayor: los que contribuyan con $200 A $400. (25 en total)

Estos recibirán como agradecimiento un jon y una camiseta de

Gagá pa’l pueblo.

Mambosa: los que hagan una contribución de $450 en adelante. (abierto)

Estos recibirán como agradecimiento: una camiseta de Gagá pa’l pueblo, un jon, y un DVD del cierre oficial de Gagá pa’l pueblo 2014


Celebrando a Santa Marta 2012


Gagá pa’l pueblo es uno de los eventos más importantes del accionar cultural dominicano en la ciudad de Nueva York en los últimos 20 años. Este es un evento único en el cual confluyen todas las ramas del que hacer cultural, representadas por pintores, artistas gráficos, músicos, cantantes, poetas, bailadores, actores, actrices y activistas comunitarios. Todos hermanados con un solo propósito: el Gagá . Mostrando y compartiendo nuestra cultura con toda la comunidad de Washington Heights & Inwood y en general con todo el estado de Nueva York; al mismo tiempo compilamos y analizamos los aportes culturales de los demás grupos étnicos de esta ciudad.

La mayoría de los integrantes de Gagá pa’l pueblo poseen una amplia experiencia en la coordinación y dirección de múltiples eventos de esta naturaleza que incluyen a: "Quisqueya en el Hudson", "El carnaval del Boulevard", "Ya llegó la virgen" y "Atardecer musical" entre otros.

Ayúdanos a continuar abriendo puertas, has tu donación y sé parte de la historia. Ningún aporte es pequeño.

Miembros de la audiencia bailando palos durante el cierre del 2013

Detalle altar del día de Santa Elena 2013

Gagá pa’l pueblo en la librería comunitaria Word Up diciembre 2013 niño hebreo aprendiendo a bailar gagáligad


Para la realización de este evento el único obstáculo que tenemos es el económico, por esta razón necesitaos de tu ayuda monetaria. Si no alcanzamos la meta de esta campaña nos veremos obligados a reducir las actividades del evento. También tendríamos que renegociar con las agrupaciones que se estarán presentando.

    Te pedimos que compartas esta campaña con tus contactos en las redes sociales.

    Utiliza las herramientas de Indiegogo y ayúdanos a lograr nuestra meta

story:
Story of My Book

We Pretend They’re Fireworks is a dystopian fiction novel about mental health and, just as importantly, the importance of not being afraid to reach out for help when you need it. Follow Lacey Matthews, the main protagonist, as she learns the importance of reaching out after periods of hardship.

My name is Hannah Kernal and I am the Author of We Pretend They’re Fireworks. I wrote this book because I believe that I have an important message about mental health that needs to be put out there! I really needed to hear something like this story when I was younger and dealing with mental health for the first time. I hope that I'll be able to pass on what I've learned to someone who might need it now or in the future.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will be able to connect with Lacey and her closest friends as they figure out what the heck they’re doing. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for mental health in you. And then, ultimately, I want you to see this book as something that encourages you to reach out for help when you need it. There is no shame in asking for help!

In this book, you'll read about Lacey's journey with mental health, the importance of interpersonal relationships and support networks, and the equal importance of reaching out to that support network when she's having a difficult time, as well as how her learning these things is a positive influence on the people around her.

You will love this book if you love dystopian fiction or conversations about mental health.
We Pretend They’re Fireworks is a dystopian fiction novel that speaks to young adults and those who take an interest in mental health who are interested in increasing their mental wellbeing, who want to increase mental health awareness, and who want to read a story about both of those things

The Book - We Pretend They’re Fireworks

The novel comes from the point of view of Lacey Matthew, a half white and half Asian girl who is living in Pennyworth. The novel begins with her best friend, Blue, attempting to commit suicide. With limitations on how socially acceptable emotions are in her hometown, Lacey has to figure out how the heck she’s supposed to survive mental health issues (Blue’s and her own) and an onslaught of other issues coming down and around her.

We Pretend They’re Fireworks takes place in a small American town, Pennyworth, where the people in power have decided that being anything but happy is out of the social norm. Citizens of Pennyworth are taught from a young age to keep their “chin up” in public and to deal with their “problems” on their own.

I decided to write this book as a dystopian fiction because it’s one of my absolute favorite genres to read, and because the genre really strongly lends itself to satire and social commentary, which is really what We Pretend They’re Fireworks is. It’s a social commentary about the fact that the social norm is one that shuns the reality of emotional vulnerability; something that everyone (including me!) has, unfortunately, been subject to historically.

What I Need & What You'll Get


This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 
  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December 2019
  • The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for My Book - to make help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this [Winter of 2019]

When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish

  • A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share experience the experiences of writing my book
  • And more...

About the Author

Hannah Lin Kernal is an English student at UCLA, as well as a competitive ballroom dancer, singer, songwriter, pianist, and guitarist. She also has a blog she has dubbed “Just a Musing Student,” which can be found at JustaMusingStudent.Wordpress.com.

She wrote this book because she has a deep passion for mental health and has had many experiences with the fictional events that take place in the book, including depression and sexual assault. She believes that everyone should find people to whom they’re comfortable talking and that bottled up emotions can serve to exacerbate problems, mental health-related or otherwise.

Hannah is also a full-time klutz and a betta fish mom. You can probably find her playing Animal Crossing, being overly concerned for Percy the fish’s health, or getting excited about stationery and bullet journaling.

For more information, you can connect with Hannah at hlinkernal@gmail.com, and on Instagram @lilhanbanan_.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #WePretendTheyreFireworks and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press (@NewDegreePress) so we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page

Please share my book to 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much of all of your love and support!

Best wishes!
Hannah Kernal

story:
Story of My Book

As a result of technology disrupting multiple industries, we are going through a time where uncertainty is forcing us to rethink our journeys. Whether we are looking to change our careers, join a new team, or get clarity on our purpose, a wealth of knowledge exists that can assist us in aligning our compass.

My name is Pablo Feliciano, and I am the author of GANAS - Getting Across Nonlinear Journeys And Succeeding. I've always been fortunate for all the help I received along the way in my untraditional path. I wrote this book as one of the ways of paying it forward. The instructor in me wants to reach those that lack the opportunity or resources to join my class. As a product manager, I want to empower teams with a product-led mindset. And, as a friend, I want to support you and gift you a compass for the journey ahead.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover a mindset that will help you navigate the world of uncertainty. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for a product-led mindset in you. And then ultimately, I want you to see this book as a tool to help you navigate moments that are nebulous as you continue in your journey and pursue your North Star.

In this book, you'll learn about the interconnections of a product-led mindset:

  • We'll learn nonlinear journeys as was the case to the humble start behind Hot Flamin' Cheetos
  • We'll explore the collaboration behind IDEO's design thinking workshops and the journeys of two IDEO instructors
  • We will extend on empathy and see how it sparks new products and initiatives such as Google's Product Inclusion team

 

You will love this book if you are a student of business and listen to How I Built This with Guy Raz. GANAS is a non-fiction book that speaks to those that are curious about preparing themselves for the disruptions to come or those looking to create a new path that’s never been traveled before. 

 

The Book - GANAS

The book is written in Three Parts...
Part 1 contains the introduction + additional chapters. You'll learn about the humble beginnings of one of the world's most popular products, and how the groundwork that makes them come to life connects to teachings from the Greeks and Romans. You will learn to analyze the playing field you're working under, or what to look for when joining a new team. As a business owner/team leader, you'll have an appreciation for building a culture...not just "time telling."

Part 2 contains Chapters 4 - 8. In this section, we explore four foundational pillars: developing an appreciation for information, stepping into unknown territory, working with what we have, and sharing our work with the others and the world. In business school, we learn about the importance of developing a mindset to scale our businesses. You will learn the elements of a product-led mindset and its usefulness as a primer for any team collaboration. We uncover the missing chapters neither taught in the MOOC(s) nor in-person training(s).  Before putting your team through that agile transformation or product training, this section is for you.

Part 3 contains Chapters 9 - 10. In this last part, we learn of a framework that allows us to put a mindset to work, and dig into the powers of community, an integral part shared in Part 1. We'll put the concepts covered throughout the book into practice in what we call "The Problem Space." The world is a team sport, let's train and learn together!

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:

  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December 2019
  • The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for My Book - to make help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this winter

 

When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.



I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish
  • A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share experience the experiences of writing my book
  • And more...

 

About the Author

Pablo Feliciano is the founder of High Street DC, a product management firm helping organizations transform into product-led teams. Always putting the customer first, High Street DC believes in empowering others through education and building culturally-centric products that add value to all users.

Pablo, a technical product manager, has a passion for building products, sharing knowledge, and sparking curiosity in others. As a former software engineer at AOL, Pablo worked on AOL AIM and AOL Publishing.

Pablo has been fortunate to have worked and consulted for companies/organizations such as AOL Advertising, Home Depot, Capital One, Digicel, Internal Revenue Service, State Department, National Science Foundation, and startups. While working for Digicel, in Haiti, Pablo started Ralfe's Dash, a grocery delivery startup to empower local Haitian women with entrepreneur skills.

In the community, Pablo led the Amigos@AOL affinity group. Outside of the office, Pablo has mentored youth through Year Up and Edu-Futuro. Pablo also served on Edu-Futuro's Board as a member and chair. "In recognition of his exemplary service in the classroom, Pablo has been selected as a member of General Assembly's Distinguished Faculty program." Today, you'll most likely find Pablo in the classroom, organizing a community soccer pick-up game, or going on a long hike.

For more information, you can connect with Pablo at highstdc@gmail.com and @PABBYG.

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family, and network. Please use #ganasbook #makepabloanauthor and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.
  • You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page
  • Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much for all of your love and support!

Thanks again,
Pablo

story:
Original Poetry, Original Art

My goal is to create a beautiful, hardback poetry collection in collaboration with my friend and spectacular artist, Josie (see her art here; the style will be similar to her Botanicals series).  

The reason I want to crowdfund this project is twofold: 1) I don't have enough money to fund it myself and still feed my children, and 2) I believe in the impact of community on art. Community is the very reason I've written any of the poetry in this book at all, and I want it to be the reason this book comes into the world.

I've been writing poetry since I was a kid, as a means of struggling with the tensions in my heart, my faith, and the world we live in -- tensions of hope and despair, faith and doubt, light and darkness, etc. My poetry has been published in Fathom, Barren Magazine, Kingdoms in the Wild, Reformed Worship, and Foundling House, among others. This will be my first self-published poetry collection, and I want to create something stunning.

What We Need & What You Get

I am raising $1,200 to cover printing costs and fees, and to compensate Josie for her art and design work on the project.

You can consider your investment in this as a pre-order. 

$2+ receive their name in the book credits as supporters.

$10+ receive an e-book version.

$25+ receive the hardback, slip-covered copy, and I'll sign it if you're into that.

$50+ receive an original art print from the season of their choice. 

If you want to spend $200, you'll get all of that plus one of the original art pieces.

If I break even, I will be over the moon. If I make it only part of the way there, I will use any funds I receive toward eventually making this book a reality. If I go way beyond the goal, I will push any excess funds toward my next project, a poetry collection entitled Words for the Church.

The Impact

"We talk of impact,
as if by force, we will be remembered,
as if by speed and escape, old pains will pass away.

But it is in slow erosion, ice seeping into rock,
smelling of shrapnel, cold and hot at once;
the caress of a yellow sky
at four in the afternoon, eastern;
the silent light of Indiana

broken only by sparrow-call...
the wind streaming from the rich and fallow field:
These are embedded so deep 

my skin has closed over them.
These can't be removed.
These make us, if we let them,
and when we return to them broken by motion, 

they embrace us as old friends."

- excerpted from solace: poems for the broken season

If you've gotten this far, I probably don't need to convince you of how important it is to make beautiful things, or write poetry, or support artists. Why are things like art, music, poetry, dance, cinema, or story important? Because if I told you something true you would understand the truth, but if I wrote you a poem about it or created a piece of art, you would love the truth. 

This project is a work of love, truth, and hope. If you support it, you're putting something true and beautiful out into the world that you yourself will also get to enjoy.

Risks & Challenges

The primary risk factor will be timing. My wife and I (but yeah, she's doing all the hard work) are having a baby in November, so running this campaign right now means hopefully finalizing everything right around that time. So, yikes. But the good news is that it's already written.

My first goal is to get this book out by Christmas. My second goal is to get it out by early January. If I don't get it out to you by Christmas, I'll notify you immediately with a snappy haiku.

Of course, the secondary risk factor is not making enough money to put this into motion, in which case it will take longer to get everything going. So in some sense, timing will depend on that.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help me out by sharing this campaign with your friends via word of mouth and social media - even if you can't support financially! Getting the word out is HUGE, no lie. 

Follow me @solacepoems on Instagram for snippets of poetry from this book and other projects, and @chriswheelerwrites (on both IG and FB) for general life and writing updates. Check out my blog too (www.chriswheelerwrites.com). If you like what you see, share it with others.

And if you think of it, would you pray for all of this? My biggest prayer is that this book would be an encouragement to anyone struggling to find hope in darkness, doubt, or despair, that we would all believe that God's love for us is infinite and true.

Original Poetry, Original Art
My goal is to create a beautiful, hardback poetry collection in collaboration with my friend and spectacular artist, Josie (see her art here; the style will be similar to her Botanicals series).  
The reason I want to crowdfund this project is twofold: 1) I don't have enough money to fund it myself and still feed my children, and 2) I believe in the impact of community on art. Community is the very reason I've written any of the poetry in this book at all, and I want it to be the reason this book comes into the world.
I've been writing poetry since I was a kid, as a means of struggling with the tensions in my heart, my faith, and the world we live in -- tensions of hope and despair, faith and doubt, light and darkness, etc. My poetry has been published in Fathom, Barren Magazine, Kingdoms in the Wild, Reformed Worship, and Foundling House, among others. This will be my first self-published poetry collection, and I want to create something stunning.

What We Need & What You Get
I am raising $1,200 to cover printing costs and fees, and to compensate Josie for her art and design work on the project.
You can consider your investment in this as a pre-order. 
$2+ receive their name in the book credits as supporters.
$10+ receive an e-book version.
$25+ receive the hardback, slip-covered copy, and I'll sign it if you're into that.
$50+ receive an original art print from the season of their choice. 
If you want to spend $200, you'll get all of that plus one of the original art pieces.
If I break even, I will be over the moon. If I make it only part of the way there, I will use any funds I receive toward eventually making this book a reality. If I go way beyond the goal, I will push any excess funds toward my next project, a poetry collection entitled Words for the Church.

story:
Que?

Patadas na boca  é toda unha lección de vida capaz de provocar un estalido de emocións dende a primeira páxina, e que instantaneamente nos somerxe nun realismo dramático e valente, combinado cunha enxeñosa e recorrente retranca.

Guntián é unha vila galega que serve de escenario a uns personaxes que verán as súas vidas cruzarse á sombra dun mundo de aparencias, no que se irá destapando unha trama imbuída de túrbidos intereses, sentimentos universais e impulsos incontrolados. A ambición enfermiza e o abuso de poder, mestúranse co amor obsesivo da vida cotiá, que non entende de clases sociais. A inxenua inconsciencia sobre a transcendencia e consecuencias que os actos propios poden chegar a ter na vida dos demais.

Quen?

Do Peirao é unha editorial con vontade de cambio, de dar a alternativa a autores que non a atopan noutro lugar, con novas e refrescantes ideas como é o empregar unha campaña preventa para valorar a aceptación e viabilidade de cada título.

Deste xeito es ti, agora que te estás expondo como colaborar, o que decide se a obra que che presentamos verá a luz pasando a formar parte do noso catálogo... porque consideramos ao lector parte fundamental do proceso.

Hoxe presentámoste a Marcos Viturro.

Licenciado en Dereito  pola  Universidade de Santiago de Compostela, gañou o seu primeiro premio literario aos  oito anos co relato infantil «O raposo dentudo». Vinte e cinco anos despois retomou a afección pola escrita gañando no ano 2013, o certame Minicontos de Outono, do extinto xornal Delunsavenres, promovido polo grupo El Progreso e o Centro PEN Galicia, co relato «Axuste de cornos». Chega agora a que é a súa  primeira novela Patadas na boca. Forma parte da Aula de Teatro Universitario de Ourense e foi membro da Escola de música creativa Drops, de Santiago.

Actualmente traballa como técnico xurídico da Administración local.

Por que?

Por aquí un fragmento do texto como mostra:

«Cando me foden, xa non sinto nada. Nin noxo, nin pena, nin gusto, nin rabia. Divago co pensamento dende que se poñen enriba miña, na procura reiterada dos mesmos soños que a día de hoxe aínda me quedan por cumprir. Coa luz case apagada evito mirarlles aos ollos, e os meus máis mínimos esforzos só se traducen en afastar a cara cando intentan bicarme na boca. Teima que teñen todos!, mais non llo tomo a mal. Dise que nesta vida unha nace ou se fai. Eu non sei se me fixen o se xa nacín puta, pero o que teño claro é que así non quero morrer. “As mulleres de mala vida acabaredes todas no ceo!”, dicía meu pai, que Deus o teña na Gloria, a pesar de que polos seus méritos, moito el non a gañou, non oh!. Sempre foi tan optimista que a quen se non se lle podería ocorrer chamarme Esperanza. Non sei que agardaba de min. Aínda así, durante moitos anos neste negocio eu era Lulú. Puxéramo unha compañeira a comezos dos noventa nun local no que traballabamos nun polígono de Lugo. Seica era por unha película, Las edades de Lulú»

Como?

Para arrincar o proxecto fixámonos como obxectivo 880€; esta é a cantidade que recadariamos se ao redor de cincuenta mecenas se fixesen, cada cal, cun exemplar desta primeira edición.

  • Tendo acceso ás galeradas de edición.
  • Recibindo un exemplar semanas antes da saída ao mercado da obra.
  • Aínda que, tamén poderías ver o teu nome nos agradecementos achegando un pouco máis.

Os fondos recadados utilizaranse como axuda para sacar adiante esta primeira edición de Patadas na boca, que sairía despois á venda.

Ademais...

Sabemos que son tempos difíciles, tamén nós os sufrimos, e é posible que non esteas en disposición de apoiarnos co teu mecenado nestes momentos... pero agardamos que se isto te chegou á alma, mesmo se talvez coñeces en persoa ao autor, trates de difundir esta campaña (facebook, twitter, blogger, boca-orella... ) para que academos a nosa meta e Marcos Viturro vexa publicada a súa obra.

Grazas polo voso tempo.
